key_points: After a severe winter storm in Texas, a poll shows Texans support reforms such as winterization and improved energy reserves.
Large majorities blame the lack of winterization of electricity (75%) and gas facilities (64%), and the unprecedented nature of the storm (68%) for its impact.
More than half of the respondents (52%) pointed to failures by Texas lawmakers as a contributory factor.
The poll was conducted by The University of Texas at Austin amongst 1,200 registered voters.
85% support requiring energy providers to weatherize facilities, while 53% favor government funding for weatherization.
Proposals like ensuring higher energy reserves and requiring ERCOT board members to reside in Texas also received substantial support.
66% experienced electricity outages during the storm, with significant numbers reporting prolonged power loss, internet issues, and financial impacts.
ERCOT, the Public Utility Commission, and the Railroad Commission of Texas received low approval ratings for their response to the storm.
Governor Greg Abbott received a 41% approval rating for his handling of the storm, slightly higher than the Texas Legislature and state-level entities.
Local governments were viewed more favorably in their response to the storm than state officials.
spokespersons: James Henson (Executive Director, Texas Politics Project)
